On Mon, 14 Nov 2005, Bradley, Todd wrote:

> Vesa, if what you're expecting to happen is for a
> fail() method (or some assert* method) in your
> Runnable to cause a failure to be printed, then
> it's never going to happen.  Short answer is that
> assertion (exceptions) can't get out of the run()
> method.  See the JUnit email list archives for
> more on this.  Or read a good JUnit book.

Thanks for the answers. I managed to trace the problem to my tearDown()
method. The fail() causes teadDown() to be called before it prints its
output. In tearDown() I called the setVisible(false) on a JFrame object,
and this call shouldn't be made from outside the event queue thread, and
now it caused an Exception. So, it was a threading issue.

What is very counter-intuitive here is that if you get an exception in
tearDown method, you don't get any output at all. Your Ant build thinks
the tests passed. Unless I was misunderstanding something, it would
be another refactoring suggestion to make sure an error is reported when
an exception is thrown from tearDown().

As for the fact that you can't get the _original_ exception out from your
Runnable, it's true, but it's not the whole truth. I think the important
point here is that as long as my tearDown method works OK, I am able to
get _some_ exception out from the Runnable, and thus make my Ant build
fail if the test fails.

Also, it's possible to call the fail() method from inside the Runnable,
as long as it is an inner class of TestCase. This is how it looks when I 
do that:

java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
        at java.awt.EventQueue.invokeAndWait(EventQueue.java:851)
       ...
Caused by: junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
       ...

So, I don't directly get the AssertionFailedError out from Runnable, but I
do get some exception anyway. If I needed the original exception, I could
unwrap it from the InvocationTargetException, but I don't need that here,
as the InvocationTargetException is enough to make my build fail
appropriately.

Currently it seems that I'm able to handle my simple need with plain
JUnit, but I will consider those GUI testing frameworks for more
comprehensive testing.

Thanks,
Vesa
